name: Career Growth
description: Career Growth across these episodes focuses on how to make better role and company decisions, build the skills and relationships that compound over time, and stay effective (and healthy) as scope and pressure increase. It addresses questions like: what to optimize for at different career stages, how to seek high-signal feedback and mentorship, how to become more strategic and executive-minded, and how to avoid common traps like prestige-chasing, misfit roles, and burnout.
subtopics: Choosing the right next role: how to evaluate company stage, product/growth realities, leadership quality, and your fit beyond title/comp
Compounding skills for seniority: moving from execution to strategy, conviction under ambiguity, and operating like an executive
Using feedback and relationships as a growth engine: high-signal input, difficult conversations, and building trust across differing “realities”
Maximizing impact through project selection: picking “white space,” clarifying environment constraints vs skill gaps, and aligning work to business outcomes
Leadership under pressure: managing energy, resilience, and mental health; recognizing burnout signals and redesigning success
Career changes and satisfaction: identifying the real “progress” you’re seeking and avoiding feature-based decisions that lead to worse fits
common_frameworks: Jobs-to-be-Done for career decisions (progress sought; features vs desired experiences; avoiding mis-hires/mis-moves)
Structured advice gathering / “Curiosity Loops” (ask better questions, pick the right advisors, increase signal-to-noise)
Role/company evaluation frameworks (stage-fit, growth/product reality checks, onboarding/activation truth vs brand promise, leadership diligence)
Environment vs skills diagnosis (separating contextual constraints from personal capability gaps to choose better projects/roles)
Executive operating mindset (think in revenue/CEO/board terms; storytelling and influence; accountability under ambiguity)
Energy and burnout management (monitor red-alarm signals; manage energy not just time; redefine success to sustain performance)
